AttributeValuesData.AttributeValue: fragrant, pyramidal evergreen with aromatic resin in blisters on the bark
dull green, later with grayish areas, smooth except for numerous raised resin blisters; eventually breaking up into small reddish brown, irregular scaly plates, 1/2" thick

The Balsam Fir is a very hearty evergreen found throughout the lakes region of the upper Midwest. It is extremely fragrant and has an attractive, symmetrically pyramidal growth pattern. Both of these characteristics make it a popular choice for Christmas trees. Balsam Fir can be identified by the flat, dark-green needles which have white, silvery bands of stomata on the underside. The branchlets of the soft needles are springy and in days gone by were used in mattresses and pillows for lumbermen and campers in the northern woods providing comfortable and aromatic rest. The fruit is a dark violet cone when young ripening into a gray-brown cone when mature. The bark of all but the very older Balsam Fir has blisters containing aromatic resin. This resin is so pure and transparent, it can be used for cementing microscope lenses and mounting microscopic specimens in laboratory experiments. Unfortunately, the resin is highly flammable and in a forest fire can quickly lead to the demise of the tree. It prefers moist locations and readily adapts to cold climates.
Balsam Fir trees may be seen on the east side of the Performing Arts Center and the northeast side of the Darrell Krueger Library.
male-catkin-like, yellow, developing from the underside of the leaf axil
cone, dark violet when young, 2-4" long, turning gray-brown and resinous at maturity; soon after the ripening of the seeds the scales fall off, leaving only the central axis

5/8-1" long needles arranged in 2 lateral sets with a V-shaped parting between, upper surface shining dark green with interrupted lines of stomata towards the tip, lower surface with 2 gray bands of stomata, typical balsam odor
